column4: for general desktop use, which file system has better overall performance, ReiserFS, or Ext3
reiser is faster in some cases. But I've found it to be markedly less reliable than ext2/3
less reliable in what sense?  not trying to nitpick, just trying to learn, and understand more.
we have a couple of terabyte storage servers at work - two different ones, with different stuff installed, but both running reiserfs.
every three or four months on average, one of them will develop random filesystem corruption and need to be brought down to maintenance mode for fsck.
so they loose data more frequently, or require file system checks more often then Ext2,3.  Now that makes perfect sense.  thank you for the explination.
now, we've not yet lost anyting important, but...
on the laptop I'm less worried about it, as there isn't anything terribly important.  but I could see having to perform maint. on the file system as a PITA
generally, you're better off using ext2/3
unless you have an actual use case for speed.
I'd happily use resierfs for a news spool - after all, reiser makes a huge speed increase there and who cares if it fails...
but for my root or home partitions? forget it.
between Ext2 and Ext3 the major change is journaling correct?  On the laptop I'd bet Ext2 is a better choice as it would/might hit the drive less frequently.
ext3 is almost always a better choice. It *is* very slightly slower, mind, but it's very, very solid.
thanks for the brief, but useful lesson in file systems :)
the best part is I feel like I got a good, solid, technical answer to my question, rather then the typical Fanboy crap I've been reading on a bunch of sites.
